node.text: A quick clearing of the confusion surrounding dietary protein stored as fat. These are the ‘Cliffs’ of an upcoming article in the next issue of AARR (alanaragon.com/aarr). My protein also book goes into the details (alanaragon.com/books). Link is in my profile. #brotein

node.title: Can protein be stored as fat?

node.text:
You gotta give Gary Taubes credit for being newsworthy :)... Here are my thoughts on renowned skeptic & science advocate Michael Shermer’s recent endorsement of Taubes and his crusade for keto.
#science #diet #evidencebased #keto #doyoueven

node.title: KETO: My thoughts on Shermer giving Taubes some shine

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Alan Aragon on August 22, 2021. May be an image of text.

node.text:
No offense taken! I encourage skepticism & critical thought. Hopefully I can provide more nuance & clarity missing in the short video clip. Firstly, I never made the claim that excess protein is never accompanied by fat gain. In the vid, I discussed Bray et al's findings of equal body fat gain from 3 different protein intake levels in hypercaloric conditions. The point is that in hypercaloric conditions in a mixed macronutrient diet, increased oxidation &/or lean mass partitioning occurs with protein, alongside increased fat conversion & adipose storage of non-protein macronutrients. I'll quote Bray et al's conclusion (PMID: 22215165): "Calories alone, however, contributed to the increase in body fat. In contrast, protein contributed to the changes in energy expenditure and lean body mass, but not to the increase in body fat."

Secondly, the claim that Americans consume more protein than necessary is false. NHANES & CDC estimates show a consumption of 1.17 & 0.92 g/kg in men & women, respectively. Is that more than the RDA of 0.8 g/kg? Yes, but if you think the RDA is adequate - let alone optimal, I have a whole other lecture for you. The claim that this is taxing on the kidneys is unfounded. A recent 28-study meta-analysis of RCTs compared high-protein intakes (≥1.5 g/kg body weight or ≥20% energy intake or ≥100 g protein/day) with normal/lower-protein intakes (≥5% less energy intake from protein/day compared with high-protein group) on kidney function. It was concluded that higher protein intakes have a trivial to non-existent effect on kidney function (PMID: 30383278). Also, a 1-yr crossover trial involving 2.5 & 3.3 g/kg showed no harmful effects on any biomarkers of health, including liver and kidney function (PMID: 27807480).

That's just the tip of the iceberg, but I'm at the word limit. For further learning, I covered this in the upcoming issue of AARR (alanaragon.com/aarr) & in my protein book (alanaragon.com/books). Also in the ISSN Position Stand on Diets & Body Composition (PMID: 28630601) which I lead-authored, there’s a section on high-protein diets. Additional reading is the ISSN position stand on protein & exercise (PMID: 28642676).

#science

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Alan Aragon on August 21, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Michael Carrato I've been fasting and nearly 100% carnivore for3 years. Healthier than ever been, and teeth and gums are perfect. Stop preaching about diet Alan. Stick to fitness, which is what you know. 3d Like Reply 45 Author Alan Aragon Michael Carrato If I could give you a superhero name, it would be Captain Anecdote 3d Like Reply 151'.

node.text:
Quick lesson about the nature of anecdotes…

Anecdotes are not useless. In fact, formal scientific investigations are often the result of putting anecdotes to the test. Some of the most interesting published research has been done as a result of scientists taking an interest in stories from the trenches.

BUT!

It’s important to realize that anecdotes are useful for generating hypotheses, not confirming universal truths. Every single dietary approach on the planet has its own legion of evangelists claiming it’s the best approach for all.

This is where science comes in… The goal of scientific research is to remove (or at least maximally suppress) bias when investigating the relationships between the variables in question. 

Everyone is entitled to their personal observations and experiences, and these things are great for fueling scientific investigations that sometimes uncover/validate novel insights. 

However, it’s important to remember that anecdotes are at the bottom of the evidence hierarchy. Anecdotes lack protection against a range of validity threats (not the least of which is confirmation bias according to the preexistent beliefs of the storyteller).

Anecdotes are a starting point for more rigorous investigation, not an ending point for demanding blind belief.

#scientificliteracy #getsome

node.text: A quick clearing of the confusion surrounding dietary protein stored as fat. These are the ‘Cliffs’ of an upcoming article in the next issue of AARR (alanaragon.com/aarr). My protein also book goes into the details (alanaragon.com/books). Link is in my profile. #brotein

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Alan Aragon on August 14, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Carnivore Nation Diet Tribe. 14h Official Carnivore Carnivore for 3 years haven't been able to stop bleeding gums, anyone reverse bledinggis? this? 20 117 Answers'.

node.text:
When you eliminate all plant foods from the diet, you risk vitamin C deficiency (manifesting as connective tissue degradation, among other pathologies related to scurvy), unless you eat large amounts of organ meats such as liver. The vitamin C content of 100 g (3.5 oz) of cooked chicken liver is 27.9 mg. This is 31 & 37.2% of the RDA for vitamin C for men and women (90 & 75 mg, respectively). So, it’s possible to cover your daily vitamin C requirements by eating about 300 g (10.7 oz) of cooked chicken liver (which could put you at risk for excessive vitamin A). If you prefer beef liver, then you’d have to consume a hell of a lot more. A 300 g serving of beef liver would net you only ~3-4 mg. The amount of vitamin C in beef liver is impractically low.

Alternatives to eating large amounts of liver to cover vitamin C needs are to supplement the diet, or eat any one of the multitude of fruits and vegetables that are many times higher in vitamin C per serving than organ meats. It’s nearly effortless to meet daily vitamin C requirements with plant foods. Now here’s a revolutionary idea: if you like liver, fruits, and veggies, eat all of it. This way you can get the multiple health benefits of eating plant foods as well.

I’m aware that many carnivore dieters end up doing it as a baseline for an elimination/reintroduction diet to investigate which plant foods might be giving them adverse effects, and that’s fine. However, committing to strict carnivore dieting on a permanent basis because it’s heroically cool, well that’s just dumb.

One thing I’d categorically advise against is sticking to a particular diet to stay in the good graces of your internet tribe — at the expense of your health. While a sense of relatedness/social acceptance is a fundamental human need, I would advise against accomplishing this via X, Y, or Z dietary ideology. I’m not singling out carnivores, either. If you find that veganism is degrading your mental or physical health, get the hell out of it. And if you don’t like that message, that’s fine with me. You’re allowed to disagree.👍🏼
-
#saturdaysermon

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Alan Aragon on August 13, 2021. May be an image of 9 people and text that says 'Early Career Influences & @thealanaragon alanaragon.com Inspirations 20'.

node.text:
I decided to do a whole other post instead of adding to my previous one because of the caption limit (2,200 characters, this caption is about double). For those who missed it, I’m simply giving credit to some of my earlier career influences. In the current digital age, it’s easier than ever to steal/adopt/take credit for ideas/protocols/products to either feed the ego or the bank account (or both). The art of citing sources is a dying flicker in the dark. Well, I’m not about that deal. Its only right to credit the folks who put in the blood, sweat, tears, and gray hair to pave the path for further progress. Swipe to read my commentary on each person.
-
Row 1: Michael Colgan, Dan Duchaine, Will Brink (@will_brink)
Row 2: Jose Antonio (@the_issn), Brad Schoenfeld (@bradschoenfeldphd), Susan Kleiner (@powereat)
Row 3: James Krieger (@james.krieger), Bill Phillips (@billphillipsfitness), Lyle McDonald (doesn’t like to be tagged).
-
#creditwhereitsdue

May be an image of text that says 'Lyle McDonald (there's an infamous "don't tag me" joke here) is one of the most influential figures in the evidence-based niche. He was the first person to tell me that I need to write a book (this was back in 2006). Lyle has always been about 10 years ahead of the fitness industry in terms of "groundbreaking" ideas.'.
Photo by Alan Aragon on August 12, 2021. May be an image of 9 people and text that says 'Early Career Influences & Inspirations @thealanaragon alanaragon.com'.

node.text: My audience, on average, is about half my age. Unsurprisingly, much of my audience first found my work through my students who have ascended the industry ranks, and through influencers who I have influenced. I’m happy to say that I still see a handful of coaches & educators giving me credit for my work despite the fitness industry’s cutthroat competitive nature. This reminded me of the importance of giving credit where it’s due, by acknowledging individuals who blazed the trails for us and future generations of practitioners, coaches, athletes, and educators. Pictured is an incomplete collage of some of the earlier influences in my career journey. Can you name them? I’ll post more commentary tomorrow. #TBT #creditwhereitsdue #shouldersofgiants

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Alan Aragon on August 11, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'Alan Aragon @TheAlanAragon Calories matter just like gravity matters. Many variables affect calorio balance. A "magic" diet or special eating pattern is only useful to the extent that it sustains the targeted calorio balance over time. A major barrier to weight loss maintenance is overconsumption of magic.'.

node.text:
To most of my audience, this is a reminder. To some of you, this is a revelation (welcome to enlightenment).😁

#humpday #science #standdowngurus

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Alan Aragon on August 08, 2021.

node.text:
John Meadows (@mountaindog1) is one of the best-loved people in the fitness & bodybuilding community/industry. I have spoken to him once on the phone, via @bradschoenfeldphd who was training with him in person. Of course Brad wanted to do some friendly trolling and throw John on the phone and make me guess who it was, without me ever having spoken to him prior to that :)… I’ve been a big fan of John’s work, & his products (T-shirt pic is of his incredible bars which were without a doubt the best-tasting ever). All John said was that he was a big fan of my work and that hopefully we’ll get to meet up & hang out soon. I insisted that pancakes be part of the deal. 

When I hit a low point in my personal and professional life a few years back, John reached out to me with compassion, comfort, and wisdom. My experience with John is not unique. His kindness, humility, and strength of character radiated toward everyone who has been fortunate enough to speak with him or call him a friend.

John will be sorely missed, but his spirit will live on. I’m sending my most sincere condolences and hopes for strength & serenity for his family in this extremely difficult time.

RIP John “Mountaindog” Meadows. We’ll meet one day on the other side. 

#inspirit

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Alan Aragon on August 02, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'Alan Aragon @TheAlanAragon 3 steps to long-term dietary adherence: 1) Eat foods you personally prefer. 2) Eat at times that work best w/your preference, training goals, & schedule. 3) Allow/plan regular hedonic deviations from the routine. Bonus: don't let magic diet claims in various media distract you.'.

node.text:
Yeah, I know… Rebellious, controversial, and triggering stuff here. Toughest love is the bonus though. Easier said than done. :)… Happy Monday, let’s smash it💥
#realtalk #adherence #yesyoucanhavecarbspast9pm

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Alan Aragon on August 01, 2021. May be an image of sashimi and sushi.

node.text:
I’m a nutrition guy. My feed needs some food once in a while :)… This was Friday’s lunch. It’s not my typical lunch, it was more of a “Yay, Alan posted AARR” celebration. @jeana.aragon prepared the meal, and this is why I’m spoiled.

Hope you all are prepared for an awesome work week as Sunday winds down. Of course my fellow entrepreneurs don’t take weekends off, but that’s fine.😆😁👍🏼 #bigcolors

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Alan Aragon on July 30, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, standing and text that says 'AARR IS POSTED M ONS IN THE TRENCHES OR e ampiu Interview with Dylan Bair, MS, RD, LD -contest prep coach of elite competitors & champions. By Alan Aragon LONAL GOOD QUESTION Is the "10,000 steps a day" guideline rooted in good evidence? What about those who can't even break 5000 steps- are they doomed? By Alan Aragon EDITOR'S CUT Age-related anabolic resistance: overview, prevention, & mitigation. By Alan Aragon @thealanaragon alanaragon.com'.

node.text:
The new issue of AARR has been posted!!! Big thanks to the contribution of my friend Dylan Bair (@dylanbair_rd) - the legend behind the highly successful @bairaesthetics coaching company.

Featured in the pic are just a few highlights of the issue, there’s much more good stuff. Swipe left to read a message I got from an AARR subscriber, Detlev Corfeld (who happens to be a brilliant guy). I got his permission to post it, of course. :)

That’s my EAA-enriched spam for the day. Hope you all enjoy the issue. Those new to what I’m talking about, go here: alanaragon.com/aarr

PS - my recently released ebook that answers all of your burning questions about protein is available as a gift to current AARR subscribers. It’s also available for purchase for non-subbers (link is in my profile, alanaragon.com/books).

Thanks everyone, & happy Friday!

#aarr #evidencebasedfitness #doyouevenscience #knowledgeispower

We definitely have the nutrition nerdy thing in common as I'd happily settle for another forty years of reading it and boring my non-nerdy friends by incessantly talking about it!'.
